results.title: The Illustrators (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Martin Daley, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Storymakers”.
We all know that illustrators make pictures, but are they also story makers? Indeed they are! This program shows how illustrators add to the written word, how pictures tell a story, and the process of making picture books. Features Julie Vivas, Roland Harvey and Jeannie Baker.

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Jackie Farkas uses the extraordinary and harrowing oral testimony of an elderly Hungarian woman as the basis for a poetic and abstract investigation into how cinema can ‘illustrate’ such profoundly horrendous experiences. The use of found footage, elusive images of beauty and horror and sequences from ‘The Wizard of Oz’ to elucidate the narrator’s memories creates an extraordinary representation of the holocaust experience, of survival, of home and memory, and of how we can comprehend the incomprehensible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Jackie Farkas, Lucia Salinas Briones and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The voice of an Auschwitz survivor (voice provided by Zsuzsi Weinstock) is presented against a backdrop of images, both hopeful and tragic. She speaks of her childhood impressions, of a belief that she couldn’t avoid her fate and the impact of Hitler’s voice. Footage from “The Wizard of Oz” is juxtaposed against images of haystacks and has a personal significance to the narrator who wished she could go ‘home’, but realises she has none to go to.

results.title: The Idol = L'Idole
results.creator_credit: Samantha Lang, Marc Missonnier, Olivier Delbosc and Fidelite Productions
results.brief_description: Directed by Australian Samantha Lang (The Monkey’s mask), this is a tale of two different souls who find solace in each other - and a kind of obsession. Set in Paris, France in an apartment block with a winding staircase that binds the people who live there. In an empty apartment opposite the elderly resident of Chinese origin called Zao (James Hong) arrives the beautiful and melodramatic Sarah (Leelee Sobieski), a young theatre actress from Australia. Sarah wants to feign a suicide to scandalise her relationship with her married lover but until she does the deed Zao asks that he may cook for her. Together they face the prospect of the end of life, love and sexual yearning - and an enjoyment of good food. Based on the novel “A L’Heure Dite” by Michelle Tourneur.

results.title: The Idiots = Idioterne
results.creator_credit: Lars Von Trier, Vibeke Windelov, La Sept Cinema, Dr TV and Zentropa Entertainments2 ApS
results.brief_description: The second of three films (“Breaking the waves” and “Dancer in the dark”) directed by Von Trier, The Idiots too is created using a female protagonist put in a stressful situation and as a work, was created adhering to the rules of the Dogme 95 Manifesto. Karen (Bodil Jorgensen) is a lone diner in a restaurant when a mentally retarded man starts to disturb everyone and creates a scene. He, his female helper and other male simpleton coax the good-natured Karen to leave with them in a taxi. Once along for the ride Karen discovers that the men were simply pretending to avoid paying the bill. But being an “idiot” is not something the men do infrequently, in fact they are part of a small community living in a large house of men and women who all take part in the practice of ‘spazzing’ or role playing ‘idiots’ to lose inhibitions both social and sexual. The group leader Stoffer (Jens Albinus) pushes everyone to the limit to see just how far they are willing to take the practice into their personal lives beyond the select commune atmosphere of the house. Offensive or funny, dramatic or pathetic, this film about, by and for idiots will certainly challenge some viewers. Shown in competition at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival. WARNING: SEXUALLY EXPLICIT

results.title: The Icicle thief
results.creator_credit: Maurizio Nichetti, Bambu and Aries Film
results.brief_description: In his ingenious comedy, Nichetti has takena wide-eyed look at Italian cinema, past and present, and has staggered back from the vision, his mind brimming with invention. On one hand, there’s Italy’s hallowed neo-realist past; grainy, black-and-white postwar images full of stubbled, unemployed fathers, sacrficial mothers and brave bustling priests. On the other, there are the television shows that “present” these films: a wasteland of lofty critics, only too willing to interpret a director’s deepest motives and intentions- even to the director himself. Nichetti has created a hilarious movie that mixes the world of cinema and television into a comic masterpiece.

results.title: The Iced hopes of Dr Calastein
results.creator_credit: Bruce Currie, Hobart Hughes and Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative
results.brief_description: Calestein returns to his underground laboratory to continue work on his beloved virus. A day not unlike any other and yet today is different. Somehow things have gone to far, and those outside and above think its time to have a few words with Dr Calestein.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce Currie, Hobart Hughes and Sydney Filmmakers Co-operative

results.title: The Icecream treaty
results.brief_description: The Antarctic Treaty’s aim is to protect the frozen continent whilst allowing peaceful scientific research. Due to renegotiation in 1991, the seven claimants face increasing pressure from a world hungry for the Antarctic’s riches. This video looks at how the people from many countries working there survive in the harsh but stunning surroundings.
